Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Metabolic Resource Partitioning: Scaling Microbial Physiology from Individual Activity to Ecosystem Function
Award.AbstractNarration:
Human impacts have altered the movement of resources within and across landscapes. Resources drive population dynamics, mediate ecological interactions, and are the currency governing elemental cycles such as the carbon cycle. For the most part, these cycles are controlled by microorgranisms. This project focuses on the physiology and diversity of aquatic microorganisms that use terrestrially-derived dissolved organic carbon, which over the past 30 years has been increasing in concentration in lakes and streams, causing them to turn brown. Not only is this "browning" unpleasant to look at, it represents a major change in the function of critically important earth ecosystems.

The overarching goals of this research project are to link the diversity, physiology, and metabolic capacity of microorganisms to resource transformations in the environment. These goals will be addressed by focusing on resource specialization within communities, the abundance and activity of microbial specialists, and how they affect ecosystem functions. The proposed research project will achieve these goals by linking the diversity and physiology of specialized microorganisms to ecosystem functioning, specifically the carbon cycle. To accomplish this, the project will address the following questions: 1) How does variation in microbial metabolic activity influence the transformation rate and the fate of resources? 2) Do microbial diversity and metabolic activity provide insight into resource specialization and the transformation of resources? The project will use a combination of isotope-labeled resource tracking and single-cell approaches to understanding microbial metabolic activity and diversity. These techniques provide increased ability to track resources, such as terrestrially dissolved organic carbon, and to understand the physiology and diversity of specialized microorganisms. As such, the proposed project addresses how microbial activity, physiology, and diversity relate to ecosystem functions and the fate of resources.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Aquatic heterotrophic bacteria play a critical role in ecosystems because their biological activities determine the fate of organic compounds, such as those from the breakdown of plant-derived material. As such, the activity different types of bacteria and the composition of the entire bacterial community can have important consequences for ecosystems. In this project, we studied two components of the interaction between heterotrophic bacteria and organic compounds.

First, we studied how well different bacteria transform various organic compounds into biomass. This transformation has important consequences for ecosystems because it determines how much organic matter from these compounds enters the aquatic food web. We found that there were biological trade-offs associated with how efficiently these compounds can be transformed into biomass. In addition, we found that related bacteria have similar patterns associated with the transformation, which suggests a linkage between the composition of bacteria in the environment and the transformation of organic matter.

Second, we studied the relationship between the available organic compounds in the aquatic ecosystem and the composition of the aquatic bacterial community. We found that the number of distinct organic compounds is correlated with the number and abundance of different bacterial species. In addition, we found a significant relationship between the composition of the organic compounds and the composition of the bacterial community. These findings provide further evidence of the connection between the composition of bacteria in the environment and the resources available to them, such as organic compounds.

This research contributes to the field of microbial ecology. Specifically, our findings are important for understanding the mechanisms which determine the composition and function of bacterial communities. Our results indicate that there is a tight coupling between the types of resources available and diversity of bacteria in aquatic ecosystems. In addition, our results demonstrate critical biological trade-offs associated with important ecosystem functions which are regulated by populations and communities of bacteria. As such, this research advances our understanding of bacterial communities and provides a better understanding of how these organisms will respond to environmental changes.
